conflicts_of_interest.name: Conflicts of Interest
conflicts_of_interest.description: Opinions addressing when public officials must disqualify themselves from governmental decisions due to personal financial interests, under the Political Reform Act (Government Code 87100 et seq.), Government Code Section 1090, and common law doctrines.

issues.name: Business Entity Interest
issues.description: Whether a public official must disqualify from a decision that could financially affect a business entity in which the official has an investment, holds a position as director or officer, or is otherwise financially connected.

issues.name: Real Property Proximity
issues.description: Whether a public official must disqualify from a decision that could affect real property in which the official has a financial interest, typically based on the proximity of the official's property to the subject of the governmental decision.

issues.name: Source of Income
issues.description: Whether a public official must disqualify from a decision that could affect a source of income to the official, including employers, clients, and business partners who have provided $500 or more in income within 12 months.

issues.name: Gift Source Disqualification
issues.description: Whether a public official must disqualify from a decision that could affect a person who has given the official a reportable gift aggregating $250 or more within 12 months.

issues.name: Personal Financial Effect
issues.description: Whether a governmental decision would have a reasonably foreseeable material financial effect on the official's personal finances, distinct from their interests in specific business entities, real property, or income sources.

issues.name: Section 1090 Self-Dealing
issues.description: Whether a public officer or employee is financially interested in a contract made by the board or body of which they are a member, in violation of Government Code Section 1090.

issues.name: Post-Employment Restrictions
issues.description: What restrictions apply to former public officials who leave government service and seek to represent private interests before their former agency.

issues.name: Public Generally Exception
issues.description: Whether an official's financial interest in a governmental decision is indistinguishable from the effect on the public generally, thereby exempting the official from disqualification.

issues.name: Legally Required Participation
issues.description: Whether an official who has a disqualifying conflict of interest may nonetheless participate in a decision under the rule of necessity.

issues.name: Remote and Noninterest Exceptions
issues.description: Whether an official's financial interest in a contract falls within one of the statutory exceptions to Section 1090's prohibition on self-dealing.

issues.name: Spousal and Community Property Interests
issues.description: Whether a public official must disqualify from a decision based on the financial interests of the official's spouse or registered domestic partner under community property law.

issues.name: Common Law Conflict of Interest
issues.description: Whether common law doctrines of conflict of interest, independent of the Political Reform Act and Government Code Section 1090, apply to prohibit an official's participation.

campaign_finance.name: Campaign Finance
campaign_finance.description: Opinions addressing the regulation of political contributions, expenditures, and campaign committee activities under the Political Reform Act.

issues.name: Contribution Definition and Political Purpose
issues.description: Whether a payment, in-kind service, or other benefit constitutes a contribution under Section 82015 of the Political Reform Act.

issues.name: Use of Campaign Funds and Personal Use Restrictions
issues.description: Whether specific expenditures of campaign funds comply with the trust provision of Section 85202(b) and the personal use restrictions of Sections 85800-85806.

issues.name: Mass Mailing at Public Expense
issues.description: Whether communications featuring elected officers constitute prohibited mass mailings under Sections 89001 and 89002 of the Act.

issues.name: Section 84308 Pay-to-Play Disqualification
issues.description: Whether contributions to officers on appointive bodies trigger disqualification from proceedings involving the contributor under Section 84308.

issues.name: Campaign Reporting and Disclosure Requirements
issues.description: How candidates, committees, and other filers must report contributions, expenditures, and loans on campaign statements.

issues.name: Contribution Limits and Inter-Candidate Transfers
issues.description: Whether contributions comply with applicable limits and whether transfers of campaign funds between candidates or committees are permissible.

issues.name: Independent Expenditures and Coordination
issues.description: Whether expenditures qualify as independent expenditures under Section 82031 or are instead coordinated expenditures treated as contributions.

issues.name: Member Communications Exception
issues.description: Whether communications from membership organizations to their members qualify for the member communications exception under Section 85312.

issues.name: Behested Payment Reporting
issues.description: Whether payments made at the behest of elected officers must be reported under Section 84224 as behested payments.

issues.name: Committee Formation and Management
issues.description: Requirements for forming, managing, and operating campaign committees under the Act.

gifts_honoraria.name: Gifts and Honoraria
gifts_honoraria.description: Opinions addressing the limitations on gifts and honoraria that public officials may accept under the Political Reform Act.

issues.name: Honoraria Ban and Exceptions
issues.description: Whether a payment to a public official for a speech, published article, or attendance at a gathering constitutes a prohibited honorarium.

issues.name: Gift Limits and Applicability
issues.description: Whether the Act's annual per-source gift limit applies to a particular public official, and how gifts must be reported on the Statement of Economic Interests.

issues.name: Gift Definition and Valuation
issues.description: Whether a particular payment, benefit, or item of value constitutes a reportable gift under the Act, and how to properly value it.

issues.name: Travel Payment Exceptions
issues.description: Whether payments for an official's travel, lodging, and subsistence are exempt from the Act's gift limits under the travel exception.

issues.name: Campaign Fund Personal Use
issues.description: Whether a particular expenditure of campaign funds or surplus campaign funds complies with the Act's personal use restrictions.

lobbying.name: Lobbying
lobbying.description: Opinions addressing the regulation of lobbying activity under the Political Reform Act.

issues.name: Lobbyist Registration and Certification
issues.description: Whether a person or entity must register as a lobbyist, lobbying firm, or lobbyist employer with the Secretary of State.

issues.name: Lobbying Disclosure and Reporting
issues.description: What payments and expenditures lobbyist employers, lobbying firms, and $5,000 filers must disclose on their periodic reports.

issues.name: Lobbyist Gift Restrictions
issues.description: Whether a lobbyist or lobbying firm may provide a gift, payment, or other benefit to a state official.

issues.name: Lobbyist Conduct Prohibitions
issues.description: Whether a lobbyist's or lobbying firm's conduct violates the specific prohibitions on lobbyist behavior set forth in Section 86205.

other.name: Other
other.description: Opinions addressing miscellaneous provisions of the Political Reform Act not primarily falling within the conflicts of interest, campaign finance, gifts/honoraria, or lobbying categories.

issues.name: Mass Mailing at Public Expense
issues.description: Whether a newsletter, publication, or other communication sent by or on behalf of a government agency constitutes a prohibited mass mailing at public expense.

issues.name: Permissible Use of Campaign Funds
issues.description: Whether a candidate, elected officer, or political committee may use campaign funds for a specific purpose under the Act's personal use restrictions.

issues.name: Statements of Economic Interests and Conflict of Interest Codes
issues.description: Whether specific officials must file Statements of Economic Interests (Form 700), which positions must be designated in an agency's conflict of interest code.

issues.name: Jurisdiction and Agency Coverage Under the Act
issues.description: Whether a particular entity constitutes a local government agency or agency subject to the Political Reform Act.

issues.name: Campaign Reporting and Disclosure Requirements
issues.description: Whether specific campaign contributions, expenditures, or committee activities trigger reporting and disclosure obligations.

issues.name: Lobbying Registration, Reporting, and Restrictions
issues.description: Whether specific activities constitute lobbying requiring registration and reporting under the Act.

queries.text: Section 87103(a) disqualification business entity investment financial interest
queries.notes: Keyword query targeting the core business entity disqualification provision. Grounded in opinions like 76188 (planning commissioner with limited partnership) and 00-014 (aviation commissioner consulting to airport tenant). Medium difficulty.

queries.text: Does a planning commissioner need to recuse if they provide consulting services to a business that operates at the airport the commission oversees?
queries.notes: Natural language question based on 00-014 (management consulting to airport tenant Sunset Aviation). Tests whether the search engine can match consulting/management relationships with business entity interest analysis. Medium-hard difficulty.

queries.text: A city council member owns a home within a landscaping and lighting assessment district. The council must vote on the annual levy for the district, which funds maintenance of streetlights, medians, and parks in the area. The assessment would apply to all properties in the district, including the council member's home.
queries.notes: Fact pattern based on 10-007 (councilmember owning home in L&L district). Blends business entity and real property interest issues. Tests whether search engine surfaces opinions addressing assessment district voting. Hard difficulty.

queries.text: real property 500 feet proximity recusal Regulation 18702.2 zoning decision
queries.notes: Keyword query using canonical terms for the 500-foot proximity rule. Grounded in 90-162 (councilmembers near street widening project) and multiple real property opinions. Easy difficulty.

queries.text: Can a city council member vote on a street widening project if their residence is 370 feet from the project boundary?
queries.notes: Natural language question directly based on 90-162 (two councilmembers with residences near street widening, analyzing different distances). Tests 300-foot vs. 500-foot materiality thresholds. Medium difficulty.

queries.text: A planning commissioner owns a rental property approximately 450 feet from a proposed mixed-use development site. The planning commission must approve the project's environmental impact report. The development would add 200 residential units and ground-floor retail. The commissioner's rental property is currently valued at $650,000 and generates $2,800 per month in rent.
queries.notes: Fact pattern grounded in proximity analysis from 90-162 and 00-018. Includes specific distance and property value details to test whether search engine can match fact-intensive proximity scenarios. Hard difficulty.

queries.text: Section 87103(c) source of income disqualification employer $500 threshold
queries.notes: Keyword query targeting the source of income provision with the $500 threshold. Grounded in 00-015 (school board member employed by nonprofit) and 00-029 (commissioner contracting with Sun Microsystems). Easy difficulty.

queries.text: Is a school board member disqualified from voting on a contract with a nonprofit organization that employs her?
queries.notes: Natural language question based on 00-018 (school board member employed by nonprofit Xanthos, disqualified from contract decisions). Directly involved source of income triggers strict materiality. Medium difficulty.

queries.text: A planning commissioner has a contract with a major technology company to write a book about urban design. The technology company has submitted an application to the planning commission for a campus expansion. The commissioner's book contract provides $75,000 in royalties over two years. The company became a source of income when the contract was signed six months ago.
queries.notes: Fact pattern grounded in 00-029 (planning commissioner contracting with Sun Microsystems for book authorship). Tests whether search engine matches book contract / source of income with planning commission decisions. Hard difficulty.

queries.text: Section 87103(e) personal financial effect official expenses income assets
queries.notes: Keyword query for the catch-all personal financial effect provision. Grounded in 00-017 (councilmember's adult son works for lumber company) and 85206 (CMAC member as nonprofit trustee). Medium difficulty.

queries.text: Does a council member have a conflict of interest when voting on development permits if the member's adult child works for a company that supplies materials to the developer?
queries.notes: Natural language question based on 00-017 (councilmember's adult son works for lumber company supplying developers). Key issue: adult children are not immediate family under the Act. Medium-hard difficulty.

queries.text: A Fort Bragg city council member owns a small retail business located 800 feet from a 420-acre former mill site that is the subject of a major redevelopment plan. Over half of the businesses in the city are located within 1,000 feet of the mill site. The council must approve a specific plan for the redevelopment, which would include new commercial zoning and infrastructure improvements.
queries.notes: Fact pattern based on A-20-022 (Fort Bragg councilmember with business interests near Mill Site). Tests public generally exception intersection with personal financial effect and real property proximity. Hard difficulty.

queries.text: Government Code 1090 self-dealing financial interest contract void ab initio
queries.notes: Keyword query using canonical Section 1090 terminology. Grounded in multiple 1090 opinions. Easy difficulty due to standard legal vocabulary.

queries.text: Can a county board member who serves as an unpaid trustee of a nonprofit hospital vote on the county's Medi-Cal managed care contract with that hospital?
queries.notes: Natural language question based on 85206 (CMAC member as unpaid trustee of nonprofit hospital with Medi-Cal contract). Tests intersection of PRA business entity analysis with Section 1090. Medium-hard difficulty.

queries.text: A water district board member is also a partner in an engineering firm. The water district is considering awarding a $2 million contract for pipeline design services. The engineering firm has not submitted a bid, but a subcontractor relationship with the winning bidder is likely. Section 1090 prohibits the entire board from entering the contract if any member has a financial interest.
queries.notes: Fact pattern testing Section 1090's board-wide prohibition. Grounded in the principle from opinions like 00-029 and 76180 that 1090 voids the contract entirely. Includes subcontractor complication. Hard difficulty.

queries.text: Section 87103(d) gift disqualification $250 threshold reportable gift donor
queries.notes: Keyword query for gift source disqualification. Grounded in 90-300 and 76100 (mayor receiving free car from dealer). Medium difficulty.

queries.text: Must a council member recuse from a redevelopment decision if the applicant gave the council member a gift exceeding $250 in the past year?
queries.notes: Natural language question grounded in the gift-source disqualification analysis from 76100 and 90-300. Tests connection between gift receipt and subsequent decision participation. Medium difficulty.

queries.text: post-employment revolving door one-year ban permanent ban Section 87400 former official
queries.notes: Keyword query for post-employment restrictions. Grounded in 10-019 (retired OSHPD deputy director) and 00-035 (retired DPA employee). Easy difficulty.

queries.text: Can a retired state agency deputy director work as a consultant on a lawsuit involving a project she supervised while in government, if she would be assisting the state rather than opposing it?
queries.notes: Natural language question based on 10-019 (retired OSHPD deputy director consulting on UCLA hospital construction lawsuit). Key issue: permanent ban exception when assisting the same side. Hard difficulty.

queries.text: public generally exception Regulation 18703 significant segment financial effect indistinguishable
queries.notes: Keyword query for the public generally exception. Grounded in 90-067 (Half Moon Bay councilmember in redevelopment area) and A-20-022 (Fort Bragg Mill Site). Medium difficulty.

queries.text: A Half Moon Bay city council member owns a historic home located within a proposed redevelopment area. The council must vote on adopting the redevelopment plan. The member argues that many other property owners in the area would also be affected and that the financial impact on her property is no different from the impact on the public generally.
queries.notes: Fact pattern based on 90-067 (Half Moon Bay councilmember with historic home in redevelopment area, disqualified despite public generally argument). Tests significant segment analysis. Medium-hard difficulty.

queries.text: legally required participation rule of necessity Regulation 18707 quorum conflict
queries.notes: Keyword query for the rule of necessity exception. Grounded in 98-224 and related opinions. Medium difficulty.

queries.text: Can a conflicted board member participate in a decision if their recusal would prevent the board from having a quorum to act?
queries.notes: Natural language question testing the rule of necessity / legally required participation exception when disqualification prevents action. Grounded in Regulation 18707 opinions. Easy-medium difficulty.

queries.text: Section 1091 1091.5 remote interest noninterest exception contract abstain
queries.notes: Keyword query for remote and noninterest exceptions to Section 1090. Grounded in 76206 and 92-125. Medium difficulty.

queries.text: Does a city council member's ownership of less than 3% of a corporation's shares qualify as a remote interest exception under Section 1091, allowing the council to approve a contract with that corporation?
queries.notes: Fact pattern testing remote interest exception for minor ownership stakes. Grounded in 1091 exception categories. Medium difficulty.

queries.text: spouse community property income disqualification conflict of interest 87103
queries.notes: Keyword query for spousal community property interest attribution. Grounded in 76206 (councilmen with spouses employed at hotel) and 90-366. Medium difficulty.

queries.text: Is a school board member required to report and potentially disqualify based on her husband's salary from a private company when they hold their assets as community property?
queries.notes: Natural language question based on 90-366 (school board reporting requirements for spouse's income via community property). Tests understanding of community property attribution. Medium difficulty.

queries.text: common law conflict of interest incompatible offices fiduciary duty People v. Darby
queries.notes: Keyword query for common law conflict of interest doctrine. Grounded in 83A059 (stockbroker councilman with developer client) and People v. Darby citation. Hard difficulty due to less-common terminology.

queries.text: A city council member is also a licensed stockbroker. One of his brokerage clients is an engineer who does development work in the city. The council member may not have a financial interest that triggers the Political Reform Act, but there may be common law conflict of interest concerns arising from the personal business relationship with a party who regularly appears before the council.
queries.notes: Fact pattern based on 83A059 (Chula Vista councilman/stockbroker with engineer-developer client). Tests whether search engine finds opinions addressing common law conflict beyond PRA statutory framework. Hard difficulty.

queries.text: Section 82015 contribution definition political purpose in-kind payment
queries.notes: Keyword query for the statutory definition of contribution. Grounded in A-20-044 (Democratic party voter contact as member communication) and 92-319 (valuing campaign literature). Easy-medium difficulty.

queries.text: If a political party pays for voter contact directed at registered party members in a specific district to support a candidate, is that payment considered a contribution subject to local contribution limits?
queries.notes: Natural language question based on A-20-044 (DPSC paying for voter contact to registered democrats for Fishman campaign). Tests intersection of contribution definition with member communications exception. Medium-hard difficulty.

queries.text: How should the cost of a campaign mailer advocating positions on thirteen ballot measures and candidates be allocated and reported among the candidates when the total cost of design, printing, and postage is $2,400?
queries.notes: Natural language question based on 92-319 (valuing campaign literature for multiple measures/candidates). Tests nonmonetary contribution valuation. Medium difficulty.

queries.text: campaign funds conference travel expenditure personal use Section 85800 governmental purpose
queries.notes: Keyword query for campaign fund use restrictions. Grounded in 90-596 (senator sponsoring lobbying conference) and 90-393. Easy difficulty.

queries.text: May a state senator use campaign funds to pay for the costs of a conference on the lobbying process that the senator is sponsoring for local public officials in his district?
queries.notes: Natural language question directly based on 90-596 (Senator Davis lobbying conference). Tests directly related to governmental purpose standard. Medium difficulty.

queries.text: Section 89001 mass mailing public expense newsletter elected officer 200 items
queries.notes: Keyword query for mass mailing restrictions. Grounded in I-19-145 (Facebook tagging of council members) and 88275. Easy difficulty.

queries.text: Does tagging a city council member on a government agency's Facebook post violate the mass mailing prohibition when the tag sends the post to the member's friends' news feeds?
queries.notes: Natural language question based on I-19-145 (city staff tagging council members on Facebook). Tests application of mass mailing rules to social media. Hard difficulty due to novel technology application.

queries.text: Section 84308 pay-to-play contribution disqualification appointive body license permit entitlement
queries.notes: Keyword query for the pay-to-play disqualification provision. Grounded in 92-031 (subcontractor contributions to transportation commission) and 09-068. Medium difficulty.

queries.text: Do contributions from subcontractors who are specifically named in a contract proposal before a county transportation commission trigger the pay-to-play disqualification under Section 84308?
queries.notes: Natural language question based on 92-031 (subcontractor contributions to LA County Transportation Commission). Tests scope of Section 84308 to reach indirect beneficiaries. Medium-hard difficulty.

queries.text: campaign statement electronic filing signature requirement Section 84615 verification
queries.notes: Keyword query for electronic filing and signature requirements. Grounded in A-18-066 (electronic signatures on campaign statements). Medium difficulty.

queries.text: Can a campaign consultant electronically sign campaign statements and reports on behalf of the candidate or treasurer when filing electronically?
queries.notes: Natural language question based on A-18-066 (SouthTech Systems electronic signature question). Tests understanding of who must verify campaign statements. Medium difficulty.

queries.text: contribution limits slate mailer organization Section 84305 inter-candidate transfer prohibition
queries.notes: Keyword query for contribution limits and slate mailer rules. Grounded in 90-546 (four candidates controlling slate mailer) and 97-363. Medium difficulty.

queries.text: If four candidates jointly produce a slate mailer recommending each other and control who is included on the slate, does the mailer qualify as a slate mailer organization product, or must each candidate pay their pro-rata share to avoid making contributions to each other?
queries.notes: Fact pattern based on 90-546 (candidates controlling slate mailer production). Tests distinction between commercial slate mailer organizations and candidate-controlled mailers. Hard difficulty.

queries.text: candidate-controlled committee independent expenditure Section 85501 First Amendment
queries.notes: Keyword query for independent expenditures by candidate committees. Grounded in 14-148 (Reed case on Section 85501 constitutionality). Medium-hard difficulty.

queries.text: After a court ruled Section 85501 unconstitutional, may a candidate-controlled committee make independent expenditures to support other candidates, and from which account must those expenditures be made?
queries.notes: Natural language question based on 14-148 (Reed case decision allowing candidate-controlled committee independent expenditures). Tests post-judicial-ruling campaign finance guidance. Hard difficulty.

queries.text: Section 85312 member communications political party registered voters contribution exemption
queries.notes: Keyword query for the member communications exception. Grounded in 10-034 (political party mailers to registered voters) and A-20-044. Easy-medium difficulty.

queries.text: Are mailers sent by a political party central committee to the party's registered voters advocating for specific candidates exempt from local contribution limits as member communications under Section 85312?
queries.notes: Natural language question based on 10-034 (political party central committee member communications). Tests member communications exception scope and interaction with local ordinances. Medium difficulty.

queries.text: behested payment Section 84224 elected officer $5,000 reporting threshold governmental purpose
queries.notes: Keyword query for behested payment reporting. Grounded in I-20-017 (Treasurer Ma fundraising for KIDS program). Medium difficulty.

queries.text: Must a state treasurer disclose funds raised by a government investment board she chairs for a government savings program as behested payments, even though the funds serve a governmental purpose?
queries.notes: Natural language question based on I-20-017 (Treasurer Fiona Ma / SIB / KIDS program). Tests behested payment definition when fundraising is for a government program. Medium-hard difficulty.

queries.text: committee formation $1,000 threshold Section 82013 bank account requirement broad-based political committee
queries.notes: Keyword query for committee formation rules. Grounded in 90-551 (Socialist Workers Campaign Committee) and 06-071. Medium difficulty.

queries.text: A small political committee has existed for three months, has contributions from 40 donors, and has contributed to two candidates. The committee wants to make independent expenditures beyond the per-candidate contribution limit. Does the committee qualify as a broad-based political committee, and what are the contribution limits that apply?
queries.notes: Fact pattern based on 90-551 (Socialist Workers Campaign Committee not meeting broad-based definition: requires 6+ months, 100+ contributors, 5+ candidates). Tests committee classification criteria. Medium-hard difficulty.

queries.text: Section 89501 honoraria ban designated employee speech article payment
queries.notes: Keyword query for the honoraria prohibition. Grounded in 95-133 (transportation commissioner writing op-ed articles). Easy difficulty.

queries.text: May a local transportation commission member who is a designated employee under the city's conflict of interest code accept payment for writing op-ed articles for local newspapers on topics unrelated to transportation?
queries.notes: Natural language question based on 95-133 (Klein writing op-eds for Irvine newspapers). Tests scope of honoraria ban even when writing is unrelated to official duties. Medium difficulty.

queries.text: Section 89503 gift limit exemption non-elected part-time governing board higher education trustee reporting
queries.notes: Keyword query for the higher education trustee gift limit exemption. Grounded in 09-039 (CSU trustee exempt from gift limit but subject to reporting). Medium difficulty.

queries.text: Is a part-time trustee of the California State University who was appointed by the Governor exempt from the Act's annual gift limit, and must they still report gifts on their Form 700?
queries.notes: Natural language question based on 09-039 (Henry Mendoza, CSU trustee). Tests Section 89503(d) exemption for non-elected part-time higher education board members. Medium difficulty.

queries.text: May a local elected official accept free roundtrip transportation and lodging from a private company to give a speech at their corporate retreat, and what are the gift reporting and conflict of interest implications?
queries.notes: Natural language question based on 00-266 (Supervisor Robey accepting travel to Hawaii from Guenoc/Langtry winery). Tests speech exception, spousal gift attribution, and disqualification consequences. Medium-hard difficulty.

queries.text: gift definition valuation Section 82028 payment personal benefit consideration reportable
queries.notes: Keyword query for gift definition and valuation rules. Grounded in 00-266 and 03-151. Easy-medium difficulty.

queries.text: Section 89506 travel payment exception government foreign government lodging subsistence gift limit
queries.notes: Keyword query for travel payment exceptions. Grounded in 17-213 (China trip payments for Mayor Wright and Councilmember Kowalczyk). Medium difficulty.

queries.text: A foreign government agency pays for a California mayor's travel, lodging, and meals during an official trade mission to promote bilateral business investment. Are these payments subject to the Act's gift limits, or do they qualify for the travel exception under Section 89506(a)(2) for payments from government entities?
queries.notes: Fact pattern based on 17-213 (Sichuan Provincial Government and Haikou City paying for California officials' China trip). Tests government-source travel exception. Medium difficulty.

queries.text: surplus campaign funds donation nonprofit Section 89519 leaving office personal use restriction
queries.notes: Keyword query for surplus campaign fund restrictions. Grounded in 11-051 (donating surplus funds to Yuba County schools) and 95-303 (self-compensation). Medium difficulty.

queries.text: May a county supervisor donate unspent campaign funds from a reelection campaign to public schools in the county?
queries.notes: Natural language question based on 11-051 (Supervisor Stocker donating surplus funds to Yuba County schools). Tests permissible use of active campaign funds for charitable donations. Easy-medium difficulty.

queries.text: lobbyist registration requirement Section 86100 lobbying firm ethics course certification renewal
queries.notes: Keyword query for lobbyist registration and certification requirements. Grounded in 15-150 (lobbyist changing firms and renewal vs. new registration). Easy difficulty.

queries.text: If a registered lobbyist leaves one employer and starts their own lobbying firm several months later, are they considered a new lobbyist who must take the ethics course within 12 months, or are they renewing a prior registration with an earlier ethics course deadline?
queries.notes: Natural language question based on 15-150 (Julie Snyder leaving Housing California to start own firm). Tests distinction between new registration and renewal. Medium difficulty.

queries.text: lobbyist employer reporting Form 635 payments influence administrative action ratemaking PUC
queries.notes: Keyword query for lobbying disclosure in ratemaking proceedings. Grounded in 12-158 (UCAN reporting for PUC ratemaking) and 89-629 (attorney-lobbyists at Insurance Commissioner hearings). Medium difficulty.

queries.text: Must a nonprofit consumer advocacy organization report on its lobbyist employer Form 635 the expenses it incurs for attorneys and expert witnesses who participate in Public Utilities Commission ratemaking and adjudication proceedings?
queries.notes: Natural language question based on 12-158 (UCAN/Privacy Rights Clearinghouse reporting for PUC proceedings). Tests scope of lobbying reporting for ratemaking participation. Medium-hard difficulty.

queries.text: May a registered lobbyist present a plaque or award worth less than $250 to a legislator, and is the payment for the award a reportable activity expense or a gift subject to the $10 monthly limit?
queries.notes: Natural language question based on 17-022 (lobbyist presenting plaque to legislator). Tests Section 82028(b) exception for personalized plaques under $250. Easy-medium difficulty.

queries.text: Section 86205(f) lobbyist contingency fee prohibition placement agent percentage fee
queries.notes: Keyword query for the contingency fee prohibition. Grounded in 11-081 (placement agent percentage fee) and 08-147 (lobbying firm percentage of state funding). Medium difficulty.

queries.text: A lobbying firm that assists school districts in obtaining state construction funding wants to charge a fee based on a percentage of the funds their client is awarded. The firm's services include compiling application materials and meeting with state agency representatives. Does this percentage-based fee arrangement violate Section 86205(f)'s prohibition on contingency fees?
queries.notes: Fact pattern based on 08-147 (Murdoch Walrath & Holmes providing advocacy/consulting to school districts on SFP funding). Tests distinction between contingency on legislative/administrative action vs. contingency on agency funding decisions. Hard difficulty.

queries.text: Section 89001 mass mailing public expense newsletter government agency distribution exempt
queries.notes: Keyword query for mass mailing restrictions on government newsletters. Grounded in 00-184 (San Mateo controller newsletter) and 92-247. Easy difficulty.

queries.text: Is a quarterly newsletter published by a county controller's office and distributed to other government agencies and officials exempt from the prohibition against mass mailings at public expense?
queries.notes: Natural language question based on 00-184 (San Mateo controller newsletter to government agencies). Tests inter-agency communication exemption from Section 89001. Easy-medium difficulty.

queries.text: campaign funds travel conference fees school board member Section 85801 governmental purpose directly related
queries.notes: Keyword query for permissible use of campaign funds for conferences. Grounded in 90-308 (Board of Education member attending middle schools conference in Hawaii). Medium difficulty.

queries.text: May a school board member use campaign funds to pay for travel to Hawaii and conference fees for a conference on middle schools as a method to relieve school overcrowding?
queries.notes: Natural language question based on 90-308 (Rita Walters, LA Board of Education). Tests directly related to governmental purpose standard for campaign fund expenditures on travel. Medium difficulty.

queries.text: conflict of interest code reviewing body multi-county agency Section 87300 Form 700 designated positions
queries.notes: Keyword query for conflict of interest code requirements. Grounded in 14-092 (Napa-Lake WIB as multi-county agency with FPPC as code reviewing body). Medium difficulty.

queries.text: When a workforce investment board is restructured to cover two counties under a joint powers agreement, does it become a multi-county agency with the FPPC as its conflict of interest code reviewing body?
queries.notes: Natural language question based on 14-092 (Napa-Lake WIB reconstituted as multi-county JPA). Tests code reviewing body determination for reconstituted agencies. Medium-hard difficulty.

queries.text: public agency definition Political Reform Act association hospital districts nonprofit membership fees contributions Section 85300
queries.notes: Keyword query for agency coverage and public money prohibition. Grounded in 90-026 (Association of California Hospital Districts making political contributions). Medium-hard difficulty.

queries.text: May an association of hospital districts, which is a nonprofit trade association with hospital districts as members, use membership fee revenue to make political contributions to candidates?
queries.notes: Natural language question based on 90-026 (Association of California Hospital Districts). Tests whether trade associations of public agencies are themselves public agencies, and Section 85300 prohibition on use of public moneys. Hard difficulty.

queries.text: Is the formation of a recreation and park district on land owned by a small group of developers considered a proceeding involving an entitlement for use subject to Section 84308's pay-to-play disqualification rules?
queries.notes: Natural language question based on 16-055 (Placer Vineyards Recreation and Park District formation). Tests scope of entitlement for use under Section 84308. Medium-hard difficulty.

queries.text: lobbyist employer attorney time ratemaking hearing Insurance Commissioner administrative action allocation
queries.notes: Keyword query for lobbying time allocation in ratemaking proceedings. Grounded in 89-629 (Consumers Union attorneys in Insurance Commissioner ratemaking). Medium difficulty.

queries.text: Must a nonprofit organization that employs attorneys who are also registered lobbyists report time spent by those attorneys representing the organization in ratemaking hearings before the Insurance Commissioner as lobbying activity on its lobbyist employer reports?
queries.notes: Natural language question based on 89-629 (Consumers Union attorneys in Insurance Commissioner ratemaking hearings). Tests allocation of dual-role employee time for lobbying reporting. Medium-hard difficulty.

queries.text: A water district conducts inspection tours of its aqueduct and facilities for community leaders, local officials, and occasionally state legislators. The tours cost approximately $13,000 per bus for 40 passengers. On a recent tour, one of 40 guests was a state legislator. Must the water district report the entire cost of the bus on its lobbyist employer quarterly report, or can the cost be pro-rated to reflect only the single state official's share?
queries.notes: Fact pattern based on 16-121 (Metropolitan Water District inspection tours with occasional legislators). Tests lobbyist employer reporting for mixed-audience events. Hard difficulty.

queries.text: electronic campaign statement filing signature Section 84615 candidate treasurer verification requirement
queries.notes: Keyword query for electronic campaign filing requirements. Grounded in A-18-066 (SouthTech Systems electronic signature procedures for campaign statements). Medium difficulty.

queries.text: When campaign statements are filed electronically, must the candidate or treasurer personally apply their electronic signature, or may a campaign consultant sign on their behalf through the filing system?
queries.notes: Natural language question based on A-18-066 (whether campaign consultants can sign electronically for candidates/treasurers). Tests electronic signature verification requirements under Section 84615. Medium difficulty.
